context_bundle.summary: Social psychology: Conformity (Asch), obedience (Milgram), bystander effect, cognitive dissonance, attribution theory (fundamental attribution error), social identity theory, persuasion (Cialdini's principles).

onboarding.quick_start: People conform to groups, obey authority, diffuse responsibility in crowds. We explain others' behavior dispositionally, our own situationally. In-group favoritism is automatic.
common_patterns: Conformity: Informational (they know better) vs normative (want to fit in). Increases with group size to ~4
Obedience: Authority + gradual commitment + diffused responsibility = ordinary people do terrible things
Attribution: FAE = over-attribute to disposition, under-attribute to situation for others
Persuasion: Reciprocity, commitment/consistency, social proof, authority, liking, scarcity (Cialdini)
known_errors: Fundamental attribution error - we all do it, especially for out-groups
Assuming bystanders don't care - diffusion of responsibility, pluralistic ignorance
Underestimating situational power - 'I would never' is usually wrong
Ignoring in-group bias - automatic, affects even minimal groups
